privacy_stance_summary: The respondents advocate for stronger privacy protections through greater transparency, standardized consent interfaces, and addressing regulatory gaps that currently allow tracking and data combination practices that undermine user privacy.
pseudonymisation_details: The respondents argue that the binary distinction between personal and non-personal data in GDPR Article 4.1 is outdated due to browser fingerprinting research. They identify a 'grey zone' of technical data (HTTP headers, JavaScript APIs, CPU/GPU benchmarks) that can identify individuals through their devices even though such data might be considered 'purely technical' and non-personal. This effectively critiques the assumption that technical/pseudonymous data cannot be used for identification.
pseudonymisation_quote: We argue that this distinction is no longer up to date with the state-of-the-art of research in the domain of browser fingerprinting: a grey zone of data that can reveal personal information exists between the two extremes of personal and non personal data.
legitimate_interest_position: The respondents note that GDPR provides different legal bases including legitimate interest and consent for collecting personal data, creating complexity when these overlap with ePrivacy requirements. They highlight this as a problem area requiring clarification but do not take an explicit position for or against legitimate interest as a legal basis.
legitimate_interest_quote: the second one gives different base legal including legitime interest and the consent for collecting and processing personal data. A clear question is to understand how to manage the overlapping of both texts.
key_arguments: Current transparency about data usage is insufficient; users should receive clear explanations before any data processing occurs
Server-side tagging obscures tracking detection and hampers compliance verification by data protection officers
Technical standardization of consent interfaces is needed to ensure compliance and simplify user consent processes
The ePrivacy Directive Article 5.3 should be modified to require fair interface design practices that preserve user attention and free will
Browser fingerprinting creates a 'grey zone' of data that can identify individuals but is not clearly addressed by current personal data definitions
Current regulations focus on data collection but fail to address data combination across sources which can reveal more than users consented to
The articulation between ePrivacy and GDPR is complex and needs clarification, particularly regarding overlapping requirements

notable_quotes.quote: We propose mandating a clear description of personal data usage before any data processing occurs, even in the context of providing the service
novel methods of tracking like server-side tagging which transfers a website's tracking logic to the server side obscure the detection of data being collected and transmitted

A browser fingerprint provides information that can identify a browser and a machine. Yet, in most cases, each machine or device, such as a smartphone or a laptop, is used by a single user. There is thus a strong equivalence between a machine and a browser, and the user that uses them.

A person could consent to two collections because they collect a limited set of data but combined, they provide much more information that could be damaging to the user's privacy. If the user knew before hand of such a combination, they would not have authorised them.
We propose to introduce a technical standardization for consent and explanation interfaces related to the use of personnal data

summary: This submission from Inria researchers advocates for strengthening user privacy through greater pre-service transparency, standardized consent interfaces with EU technical standards, and regulatory updates to address browser fingerprinting and data combination practices. notable_quotes.quote: The GDPR precedence mentioned in the previous point becomes a systematic blocker for fleets and shared vehicles, where personal data is inevitably present.
Companies that have no interest in sharing data could bypass the requirements of the Data Act by simply mixing generated data with personal data that would fall under the GDPR.

Article 5 of the Data Act limits the rights of data recipients, which will negatively impact start-ups and SMEs... favoring the more vertically integrated original equipment manufacturers that already hold large amounts of data.
If major SaaS solutions cannot meet the strict CRA requirements at reasonable costs, SMEs may run the risk of not launching digital products if otherwise compliance costs are otherwise too high.
In high-speed driving, human reaction times (~0.7 seconds) make real-time intervention impractical, while in business processes, mandatory oversight can limit efficiency.

summary: Schaeffler, a major German automotive supplier, seeks regulatory simplification across CRA, Data Act, and AI Act to reduce compliance burdens and enable data-driven innovation. Their core concerns are clarifying regulatory overlaps, ensuring data access rights are not blocked by GDPR when data is pseudonymized, and creating flexible standards for B2B contexts. They position GDPR as a barrier that incumbents exploit to prevent data sharing with SMEs and aftermarket competitors.

privacy_stance_summary: They strongly support reducing GDPR and ePrivacy obligations, arguing current rules are overly formalistic and divert resources from genuine privacy protection toward compliance-first routines.
legitimate_interest_position: They argue legitimate interest is too narrowly interpreted by CJEU and regulators, and propose either replacing Article 6's enumerated legal bases with a general authorization when GDPR principles are met, or significantly broadening legitimate interest to cover AI development, big data, digital platforms, and data monetization.
legitimate_interest_quote: the legitimate interest (Art. 6(1)(f)) and contractual (Art. 6(1)(b)) bases are often applied too narrowly by the CJEU, European Data Protection Board, and national authorities, leading to an overly restrictive interpretation that discourages innovation and developments in AI, digital platforms, and data-driven sectors.
key_arguments: GDPR hampers innovation and should be amended to explicitly include EU strategic interests and competitiveness as objectives

non-essential, process-heavy obligations across EU legislation that add cost and complexity without materially improving outcomes for individuals are diverting resources from genuine privacy-first practices toward compliance-first routines.

In a world where regimes such as China, Russia and others use data and AI, without self-imposed restrictions, to project influence and challenge open societies, including the Baltic region, Europe must strike a more balanced course.

This results in excessive cookie banners that obstruct the use of digital services, frustrate users, and divert attention from genuinely high-risk tracking, while offering minimal real privacy benefits.

major companies have reportedly delayed or limited advanced AI launches in the EU due to regulatory uncertainty. The EU should avoid a future where innovation occurs elsewhere while European users and businesses are left behind.

summary: This coalition of Baltic tech companies and professional associations advocates for substantial deregulation of GDPR, ePrivacy, and the AI Act, framing current rules as overly burdensome and competitively disadvantageous compared to global rivals. They propose risk-based approaches that would significantly reduce compliance obligations for most data processing, shift from consent to opt-out models for cookies and marketing, and delay AI Act enforcement for strategic reassessment. While claiming to support fundamental rights, their concrete proposals consistently prioritize business flexibility and innovation over privacy protections.

key_arguments: Horizontal simplification: harmonize definitions and reporting requirements across GDPR, AI Act, NIS2, CRA, DSA to reduce compliance duplication

notable_quotes.quote: A European Parliament study found that the accumulation of recent regulations represents a cost of €28 billion for the first year of compliance for SMEs.

Companies—especially mid-caps, SMEs and startups—must comply with parallel, sometimes redundant reporting and audit requirements. This duplication creates inefficiencies, raises compliance costs, and ultimately stifles innovation.

Similar data points (root cause, affected systems, mitigation, impact assessments - DPIA, FRIA) are submitted multiple times in different formats to different authorities (DPA, CSIRT/competent authority, market surveillance authority/ENISA, AI competent authority).
Simplification of Europe's digital rulebook is not about deregulation, but about smart regulation, agile implementation and technological facilitation.
These added layers disproportionately affect smaller players and scaleups, who must navigate 27 different interpretations of what should be a single rulebook.

summary: OpenAI's response focuses heavily on reducing regulatory complexity and compliance burdens across EU digital laws, positioning GDPR alongside other regulations as creating overlapping, costly obligations that hinder innovation and competitiveness. They propose a five-pillar framework for simplification including harmonized definitions, single reporting portals, AI-powered compliance tools, and international regulatory convergence with democratic partners. The response does not engage with specific privacy protections or data subject rights, instead framing the discussion entirely around easing compliance for businesses.

privacy_stance_summary: CIPL advocates for simplifying GDPR compliance through targeted amendments, reducing consent burdens, and adopting risk-based rather than prescriptive approaches, while maintaining accountability frameworks.
legitimate_interest_position: Strongly supports expanding legitimate interest as a legal basis, arguing there should be no hierarchy between GDPR legal bases and that over-reliance on consent creates unsustainable burdens on individuals while weakening privacy protections. Points to UK DUAA as a model for pre-approved legitimate interest activities.
legitimate_interest_quote: A future-adaptive regulatory framework should affirm that there is no hierarchy between the legal bases of the GDPR and empower the responsible use of data, supported by strong accountability measures and risk management that do not put the onus on the individual.
key_arguments: Simplification should be risk-based rather than size-based (no headcount thresholds)
Consent over-reliance creates unsustainable burden on individuals and weakens privacy
Revise Article 22 to permit beneficial automated decision-making under safeguards
Broaden scientific research exemptions to include commercial R&D and AI development
Make innovation an explicit core objective of data protection regulation
Address legal gaps limiting use of sensitive data for AI bias detection and fairness
Shift to outcomes-based international data transfer assessments
Rework cookie consent framework for low-risk analytics
Reduce redundant reporting obligations across GDPR, AI Act, DORA, NIS2, CRA
Establish unified accountability framework across all digital regulations

notable_quotes.quote: The continued preference of consent, often required across multiple digital laws, has created an unsustainable model that puts an undue burden on the individual and ultimately weakens privacy protections.
This complexity increases compliance costs and diverts resources from innovation and meaningful data protection outcomes.
Address legal gaps that limit the responsible use of sensitive data in AI development, essential to ensuring non-discrimination and fairness in AI outcomes.
The dual role of Data Protection Authorities (DPAs), protecting rights while enabling innovation, should be explicitly recognised in law.
Simplification is not merely a technical exercise, but a strategic opportunity to recalibrate Europe's digital rulebook toward clarity, coherence, and accountability.

summary: CIPL, an industry-backed privacy think tank, strongly supports the simplification agenda, advocating for targeted GDPR amendments that reduce consent reliance, expand legitimate interest, enable beneficial AI development with sensitive data, and streamline cross-regulatory compliance. Their position prioritizes organizational accountability and innovation-enabling regulation over individual consent mechanisms, while maintaining they support rights protection through risk-based safeguards rather than prescriptive rules.

privacy_stance_summary: Indeed favors streamlined data and consent approaches that reduce friction, suggesting a preference for simplifying current privacy requirements while maintaining some level of trust.
key_arguments: Use the Omnibus to enhance coherence across existing legislation
Focus on clear European institutional dialogue on timelines and practical implementation
Promote Member State regulatory cooperation
Explore refreshed and streamlined data and consent approaches that reduce friction while maintaining trust
Provide predictable, clear and proportionate guidance on the AI Act

notable_quotes.quote: The Digital Omnibus presents a constructive opportunity to promote clarity and coordination across the EUs digital rulebook
Explore refreshed and streamlined data and consent approaches that reduce friction while maintaining trust
Provide predictable, clear and proportionate guidance on the AI Act

summary: Indeed supports the Digital Omnibus as an opportunity to simplify and harmonize EU digital regulations. Their primary asks focus on regulatory coherence, streamlined consent mechanisms that reduce friction for businesses, and clear guidance on AI Act implementation. The response is high-level and does not engage with specific technical privacy issues.

privacy_stance_summary: Bolt advocates for aligning and simplifying privacy-related regulations like GDPR with other digital rules to reduce administrative burden, framing this as efficiency rather than deregulation.
key_arguments: Overlapping digital regulations create legal uncertainty and administrative duplication
Simplification should not mean deregulation but rather efficient and consistent application

Implement a unified risk-assessment framework across regulations

Avoid national gold-plating of EU rules
Harmonise transparency and data reporting across DSA and P2B frameworks
Focus on proportionality and relevance in reporting requirements

notable_quotes.quote: Simplification would not mean deregulation. It means ensuring that strong European rules can be applied efficiently, consistently, and at scale.

The interaction of overlapping instruments pursuing similar objectives—safety, fairness, and transparency—but through different processes and reporting requirements can result is legal uncertainty, administrative duplication, and fragmented national implementation.
Clearer, interoperable rules would strengthen enforcement while reducing unnecessary burdens on compliant businesses.

summary: Bolt, an Estonian platform company, argues that Europe's overlapping digital regulations (AI Act, GDPR, DSA, P2B, Platform Work Directive) create unnecessary complexity and administrative burden. They call for regulatory alignment through a once-only principle, unified risk assessments, and harmonised reporting, while preserving the country-of-origin principle to prevent national gold-plating of EU rules.

summary: BEUC, representing European consumers, firmly supports maintaining strong privacy protections and opposes any simplification that could lead to deregulation. summary: Filiera Italia, an Italian agri-food sector organization, advocates for digital simplification that balances innovation with protection and emphasizes data sovereignty. privacy_stance_summary: AER supports privacy in principle but advocates for relaxing the strict consent-based regime in ePrivacy to allow alternative legal bases like legitimate interest, arguing current rules create consent fatigue and threaten radio stations' advertising-based business models.
pseudonymisation_details: They mention pseudonymised data positively, arguing exceptions should cover collection of pseudonymised data for cross-device user experience, but do not discuss problems with pseudonymisation.
legitimate_interest_position: Strongly supports allowing legitimate interest as a legal basis under ePrivacy, aligned with GDPR, to reduce consent fatigue and ensure consistency in EU law.
legitimate_interest_quote: The ePrivacy framework should allow for alternative lawful bases for processing, such as legitimate interest and the performance of a contract, mirroring the GDPR. This approach reduces 'consent fatigue' among users and ensures consistency in EU law, especially where processing does not pose significant risks.
key_arguments: Align ePrivacy legal bases with GDPR to allow legitimate interest and contract performance
Protect audience measurement practices including through third-party providers
Allow cookie walls - media providers should be able to make content conditional on accepting cookies for targeted advertising
Create exceptions for pseudonymised data collection for cross-device user experience
Ensure browser-level consent settings do not override individual service consent requests
Balance privacy protection with sustainability of advertising-funded media

notable_quotes.quote: We have seen until now that excessive reliance on consent creates fatigue and frustration to users, while broad advertising restrictions endangers the very ability of radio stations to operate online, innovate, and provide culturally diverse content financed through advertising.

Radio and media services should have the right to make access to their content conditional on the acceptance of cookies and data processing necessary for targeted advertising. Prohibiting 'cookie walls' undermines business models and freedom to conduct business, provided adequate privacy safeguards are in place.
Any new proposal should ensure that browser-level consent settings do not override the ability of individual radio services to request and obtain meaningful, informed consent directly from listeners.

summary: AER, representing commercial radio broadcasters, advocates for significant relaxation of ePrivacy consent requirements to protect advertising-funded business models. pet_quote: The 'modernization' of the rules on cookies expressed in the call for evidence should also explicitly recognise Privacy-Enhancing Technologies (PETs) as a proportionate safeguard for the reading and storing of data (low-sensitivity data). privacy_stance_summary: Orange advocates for repealing ePrivacy metadata provisions (Article 6) to allow telecom operators to innovate under the same GDPR rules as big tech, and seeks to loosen Data Act restrictions that they argue conflict with GDPR-permitted data uses.
pseudonymisation_details: Orange argues that the Data Act's concept of 'user's non-personal data' is incoherent because if data can be indirectly linked to individuals through additional identifiers, it constitutes pseudonymized data under GDPR, making the distinction between personal and non-personal data misleading.
pseudonymisation_quote: Conversely, if the data can be indirectly linked to individuals through additional identifiers, they constitute pseudonymized data and should be treated as personal data under the GDPR, rendering the term 'non-personal data' inaccurate.
legitimate_interest_position: Orange argues that Data Act Article 8(4) conflicts with GDPR legitimate interest provisions by preventing data holders from sharing data with third parties except at user request, which they claim creates 'locked datasets' and hinders lawful innovation including AI development.
legitimate_interest_quote: Under the GDPR, data controllers may rely on lawful bases for processing personal data, such as the performance of a contract (Article 6(1)(b)) or legitimate interest (Article 6(1)(f)). However, Article 8(4) of the Data Act prevents data holders from making data available to third parties except at the explicit request of the user. This provision risks creating 'locked datasets,' limiting legitimate data uses otherwise permitted under the GDPR.
key_arguments: Repeal ePrivacy Article 6 on metadata to let telecoms operate under same rules as big tech

They frame excessive bureaucracy and consent requirements as barriers to Europe's competitiveness in connected and autonomous vehicles.

privacy_stance_summary: ITI advocates for simplifying and streamlining EU privacy rules, including repealing the ePrivacy Directive, providing more flexibility for pseudonymized data processing, and reducing documentation burdens under GDPR, while maintaining GDPR as the baseline framework.
pet_details: ITI recommends that the EU 'strongly encourage and incentivize the use of Privacy-Enhancing Technologies (PETs) to minimize privacy risks when processing sensitive categories of personal data for AI.' They also mention pseudonymization, anonymization, and synthetic data as privacy-preserving techniques that should be recognized in guidance.
pet_quote: The EU should strongly encourage and incentivize the use of Privacy-Enhancing Technologies (PETs) to minimize privacy risks when processing sensitive categories of personal data for AI.
pseudonymisation_details: ITI argues that pseudonymized data receives insufficient regulatory recognition compared to anonymized data, creating a disincentive for companies to use privacy-enhancing techniques. They advocate for treating pseudonymized data more flexibly, closer to the approach taken with anonymous data, and introducing a more realistic standard for likelihood of re-identification.
pseudonymisation_quote: Pseudonymized data is a key example. While it significantly limits the ability to link data to individuals, it is afforded little regulatory recognition compared to anonymized data. As a result, the framework provides insufficient incentives for companies to use privacy-enhancing techniques, even where they meaningfully reduce risks to individuals.
legitimate_interest_position: ITI notes that existing EDPB guidance on legitimate interests provides helpful general guidance but argues that areas remain where clear and practical guidance for companies would be welcome, particularly for AI training purposes.
legitimate_interest_quote: Similarly, existing EDPB guidance on reliance on the 'legitimate interests' legal basis provides helpful guidance on how to conduct the legitimate interests balancing test generally, but areas remain where clear and practical guidance for companies would be welcome (e.g., for AI training).
key_arguments: Repeal the ePrivacy Directive as outdated and redundant with GDPR

Include Data Act in the Omnibus scope for meaningful simplification

notable_quotes.quote: The complexity and fragmentation of the EU's tech rulebook create significant legal uncertainty and regulatory burden for innovators, which in turn restricts their ability to invest in, develop and deploy technologies and products in Europe.

The European Commission should repeal the ePrivacy Directive from the EU acquis and national transpositions should also be repealed. Specifically, the GDPR should serve as the horizontal legal framework governing the processing of personal data in the electronic communications sector.

We are concerned about the lack of reference to the Data Act in the Call for Evidence accompanying this consultation. The Data Act introduces significant red tape, legal overlaps and costs for companies.

The DPIAs and the AI Act' FRIAs – while having a different focus – cover overlapping concerns in practice. Conducting both assessments would lead to redundancy and obviously increase the compliance burden.
Data minimization does not necessarily mean using small data volumes for AI training, rather proportionality is key when applying data minimization to AI.
For certain service providers operating under multiple regulatory frameworks, this fragmentation can require a single incident to be notified to over 40 bodies across different member states.

They call for repealing the ePrivacy Directive, postponing implementation of several new regulations, narrowing Data Act scope, streamlining incident reporting to single national entry points, and providing more flexibility for pseudonymized data processing while encouraging PETs for AI development.

privacy_stance_summary: AFNOR focuses entirely on reducing regulatory complexity and administrative burden, with no mention of maintaining or strengthening privacy/data protection safeguards.

Build on international standards like ISO/IEC 42001 (AI) and ISO/IEC 27001 (security) for compliance frameworks
Ensure proportionality with phased obligations and lighter regimes for SMEs and lower-risk activities

Align requirements across NIS2, CRA, eIDAS, AI Act, Data Act, and Data Governance Act

a 'certify once, comply many' approach would allow businesses to demonstrate compliance once, with recognition across the EU digital acquis

Common specifications risk undermining this architecture by creating parallel, prescriptive rules outside the standardisation system, thereby generating duplication, fragmentation, and additional complexity for businesses
companies may need to notify several authorities across different Member States and legal frameworks, often using different formats and deadlines
safeguards are needed to prevent the indirect transfer of compliance duties along supply chains... larger companies may cascade obligations onto smaller suppliers, creating disproportionate burdens

summary: AFNOR, the French standardisation body, advocates strongly for regulatory simplification through mutual recognition of compliance ('certify once, comply many'), unified reporting via ENISA, and primacy of harmonised standards over Commission-issued common specifications. Their focus is entirely on reducing administrative burden and ensuring coherence across the EU digital acquis, with particular emphasis on protecting SMEs from disproportionate obligations and supply chain burden cascading.

summary: The Swedish Internet Foundation, as a .se/.nu domain operator and NIS2 essential entity, supports the Digital Omnibus proposal to reduce administrative burdens. Their primary concern is regulatory overlap between NIS2, CER directive, and GDPR regarding audits, supervision, and cybersecurity measures. The response appears truncated but clearly advocates for streamlined, non-overlapping EU digital regulation.

privacy_stance_summary: They strongly support reducing GDPR and ePrivacy obligations, arguing current rules are overly formalistic, constrain innovation, and should be replaced with risk-based approaches focused only on high-risk processing.
legitimate_interest_position: They argue legitimate interest (Art. 6(1)(f)) is applied too narrowly by CJEU, EDPB, and national authorities, and should be significantly broadened to clearly cover AI development, big data, digital platforms, and data monetization. They propose either making Article 5 principles a general authorization for processing (replacing Article 6 legal bases entirely) or substantially reinforcing legitimate interest as a key processing ground.
legitimate_interest_quote: The legitimate interest (Art. 6(1)(f)) and contractual (Art. 6(1)(b)) bases are often applied too narrowly by the CJEU, European Data Protection Board, and national authorities, leading to an overly restrictive interpretation that discourages innovation and developments in AI, digital platforms, and data-driven sectors.
key_arguments: GDPR should explicitly include EU strategic interests, innovation, and competitiveness as objectives alongside fundamental rights protection
Introduce risk-based approach focusing enforcement on tangible harms rather than theoretical risks
Data lawfully made public should be largely exempt from GDPR obligations
Broaden legitimate interest basis to cover AI, big data, and digital platforms
Remove 'formalistic' obligations like DPIAs, records of processing, and joint controller arrangements
Replace cookie consent banners with opt-out model limited to high-risk cookies only
Shift direct marketing from opt-in to opt-out model
Prohibit data transfers only to hostile countries (China, Russia) rather than current complex framework
Temporarily suspend and reassess the AI Act
Refocus AI Act on prohibited practices only, removing most compliance obligations

notable_quotes.quote: Non-essential, process-heavy obligations across EU legislation that add cost and complexity without materially improving outcomes for individuals are diverting resources from genuine privacy-first practices toward compliance-first routines.
Even the Commission's own advisory reports have warned that the GDPR 'hampers innovation', imposes excessive burdens, and drives up costs in the European market.

In a world where regimes such as China, Russia and others use data and AI, without self-imposed restrictions, to project influence and challenge open societies, including the Baltic region, Europe must strike a more balanced course.

This results in excessive cookie banners that obstruct the use of digital services, frustrate users, and divert attention from genuinely high-risk tracking, while offering minimal real privacy benefits.

We are concerned that the AI Act's broad scope and prescriptive compliance regime, if implemented without adjustment, could hamper Europe's AI ecosystem and leave us lagging behind more nimble competitors.

summary: This coalition of Baltic tech companies and associations advocates for substantial weakening of EU data protection and AI regulations, framing current rules as overburdensome and harmful to European competitiveness. They propose removing most GDPR compliance obligations (keeping only high-risk requirements), replacing cookie consent with opt-out, broadening legitimate interest dramatically, and suspending the AI Act for reassessment. Their position prioritizes innovation and competitiveness over current privacy protection levels, while acknowledging fundamental rights should not be 'undermined' in principle.

summary: The European Partnership for Democracy supports harmonisation efforts but strongly opposes any weakening of existing EU digital regulations. Their detailed recommendations are referenced in an attached document not included in this text.

privacy_stance_summary: Bitkom advocates for targeted GDPR amendments and risk-based simplification to reduce compliance burdens while maintaining high privacy standards, arguing current rules hinder innovation especially for AI development.
pet_details: Bitkom discusses pseudonymization and anonymization as technical measures to enable data sharing under the Data Act while protecting personal data. They propose that mixed datasets should not be treated as personal data if pseudonymized according to recognized standards and re-identification by unauthorized third parties can be effectively excluded. They also mention encryption as a safeguard for AI data processing.
pet_quote: By employing pseudonymization or anonymization techniques, it can be ensured that no directly identifiable personal information is disclosed when data is shared.
pseudonymisation_details: Bitkom identifies a fundamental problem: pseudonymized data is still considered personal data under GDPR (Recital 26), which creates conflicts with the Data Act's data sharing requirements. They note the DORA Regulation creates technical conflict by permitting pseudonymized data storage in non-production environments while GDPR treats it as personal data. They call for clear, legally binding requirements for pseudonymization and anonymization.
pseudonymisation_quote: However, it should be noted that the use of pseudonymous data does not exempt data from the obligations under the Data Act. Therefore, the proposal is: mixed datasets should not be treated as personal data if the personal data has been pseudonymized according to recognized standards and re-identification by unauthorized third parties can be effectively excluded.
legitimate_interest_position: Bitkom advocates for allowing legitimate interests as a legal basis for low-risk data processing activities currently requiring consent under ePrivacy, particularly for essential activities like analytics. They propose deleting Art. 5(3) from the ePrivacy Directive and introducing a modern, risk-based provision into GDPR that would allow essential, low-risk activities to proceed on legitimate interests basis subject to GDPR's balancing test.
legitimate_interest_quote: Deleting Art. 5(3) from the ePrivacy Directive and introducing a modern, risk-based provision into the GDPR would be the most effective simplification. This would allow essential, low-risk activities to proceed on a more appropriate legal basis like legitimate interests, subject to the GDPR's robust balancing test and safeguards.
key_arguments: Streamline cybersecurity reporting under 'one incident, one report, one mechanism' principle
Postpone AI Act high-risk requirements by at least 24 months due to delayed harmonised standards
Include the Data Act in the Digital Omnibus for holistic simplification
Address GDPR through targeted amendments - don't exclude it from the Omnibus
Reform ePrivacy Directive holistically, not just cookie rules
Delete Art. 5(3) ePrivacy and allow legitimate interests for low-risk processing
Harmonize definitions and eliminate regulatory overlaps across digital laws
Establish central EU enforcement mechanisms to replace fragmented national approaches
Create clear pseudonymization standards so properly pseudonymized data isn't treated as personal data
Maintain eIDAS as single reference for digital identity

notable_quotes.quote: Instead of delivering the promised legal clarity to support innovation made in Europe, businesses are grappling with a jungle of regulatory complexity.
Today, 94% of German companies describe their data protection compliance burden as high, and in 63% the workload has further increased over the past year.
Currently, 76% of users are annoyed by cookie banners, and 68% say they do not want to deal with them at all.
70% of German companies warn that current data protection rule hinder digital innovation.
93% of German companies affected by the AI Act report that the effort required for its implementation is considered either rather high or very high.
We are concerned, however, that the European Commission appears to be excluding the GDPR from the scope of the Digital Omnibus.

summary: Bitkom, representing 2,200+ German digital economy companies, strongly supports the Digital Omnibus as a vital opportunity to streamline EU digital regulation but urges the Commission to include both GDPR and Data Act in its scope. Their 40-page position paper calls for harmonizing overlapping requirements across cybersecurity, AI, data, and privacy laws, with specific proposals including postponing AI Act high-risk requirements by 24 months, establishing one-stop-shop incident reporting, modernizing ePrivacy by allowing legitimate interests for low-risk processing, and creating clear pseudonymization standards to enable innovation while maintaining privacy protection.

privacy_stance_summary: Salesforce supports maintaining GDPR's fundamental protections but argues data protection rules should be simplified and adapted to enable AI innovation, particularly around data subject rights, legal bases for AI training, and anonymization thresholds.
pseudonymisation_details: Salesforce argues that the GDPR's high bar for true anonymization is virtually impossible to prove, especially given modern AI capabilities. They contend this causes data intended for AI analysis to be regulated as personal data even when minimal re-identification risk exists, unnecessarily triggering full compliance requirements for low-risk applications.
pseudonymisation_quote: Because true anonymization is virtually impossible to prove, data intended for AI analysis is often regulated as personal data even if minimal risk exists. This risks unnecessarily triggering the full compliance regime (DPIAs, consent, rights of erasure) for low-risk applications.
legitimate_interest_position: Salesforce supports using legitimate interest as a legal basis for AI training, citing CNIL's June 2025 guidance as a model approach. They argue consent is impractical for AI model training and recommend the Commission promote the CNIL approach while also proposing amendments to GDPR Recital 32 to make consent more workable for AI development.
legitimate_interest_quote: Consent is a challenging legal basis to use in practice when training AI models, leaving companies with fewer options and often forcing them to rely on legitimate interest (LI), which requires a Legitimate Interest Assessment (LIA).
key_arguments: Narrow the high-risk AI designations in EU AI Act Annex III to avoid over-regulating low-risk systems
Limit data subject rights (access, erasure, objection) for AI models where data is embedded in model parameters
Develop more realistic anonymization thresholds specifically for low-risk data and AI applications
Consolidate DPIAs, TIAs, ROPAs, and LIAs into a single Integrated Risk Assessment document
Establish mutual recognition framework for AI Act enforcement across Member States
Recognize international standards like ISO 42001 for AI Act compliance
Create single national-level entry point for cyber incident reporting across GDPR, NIS2, DORA, and CRA
Align 'main establishment' definition across all EU digital frameworks
Clarify rules on cross-border data transfers and 'data in the clear' for cloud SaaS services
Provide guidance to limit vexatious Data Subject Access Requests in employment disputes

notable_quotes.quote: The goal is for data protection principles to coexist with and enable innovation, not hinder it. Consistency of laws and regulations can in fact strengthen data protection by bringing clarity and coherence on core principles.

Once data has been used to train an AI model, it becomes inextricably embedded within the model's learned parameters. 'Model unlearning' can be technically challenging or require disproportionately costly retraining of the entire model, effectively demanding the destruction of a valuable asset built on significant investment.

A fragmented legal and regulatory landscape across the 27 EU Member States creates a patchwork of rules that confuses businesses, increases compliance costs, and slows down the development and deployment of digital services.

The current compliance structure for data protection particularly as it applies to AI companies operating globally, is not streamlined for efficiency but rather based on separate, overlapping documentation requirements, involving separate, repetitive DPIAs, TIAs, ROPAs, and LIAs.

summary: Salesforce advocates for significant simplification of EU digital regulations to enhance competitiveness and enable AI innovation, while nominally supporting GDPR's core protections. Their key asks include narrowing high-risk AI classifications, limiting data subject rights for AI training data, lowering anonymization thresholds, consolidating compliance assessments, and streamlining incident reporting across multiple cyber frameworks.

privacy_stance_summary: Strongly supports privacy protections through automation (GPC) that benefits both users and businesses, arguing current enforcement primarily benefits adtech intermediaries and tech monopolies rather than citizens or European businesses.
pet_details: Extensively discusses Global Privacy Control (GPC) as a privacy-enhancing technical signal that automates user privacy preferences. GPC is a browser-based automated signal that creates single-controllership situations, reducing tracking across the internet. The author co-developed GPC and deployed it at The New York Times.
pet_quote: Developing and deploying the Global Privacy Control (GPC) as a technical system to reduce compliance costs, improve user experience, and improve the business position of media publishers with respect to tech monopolies and advertising intermediaries.
legitimate_interest_position: Argues that GPC signal should trigger Article 21 objection to processing by third-party data controllers under legitimate interest, while preserving the consumer-facing business's ability to conduct direct marketing. Notes that controller-to-controller data transfers under legitimate interest are already risky, and continuing over data subject objection is 'at best an adventurous position.'
legitimate_interest_quote: Where the legal basis is legitimate interest, the data subject is objecting to processing by data controllers other than the consumer-facing business and to the transfer of data to other data controllers, as per Article 21(1-3, 5).
key_arguments: Adopt Global Privacy Control (GPC) as an automated privacy signal under GDPR/ePrivacy framework
Enforce single controllership model - third parties should be processors not controllers
Current consent fatigue and complexity benefits only adtech intermediaries and tech monopolies
GDPR/ePrivacy framework is already flexible enough to implement GPC without legislative changes
Automation benefits both users (no popups) and businesses (reduced compliance costs)
Single controllership protects European businesses from having their audience data reused by competitors and for AI training
GPC provides sensible middle ground between 'Accept All' and 'Reject All'
Consider extending DFA to mandate browser support for GPC signal

notable_quotes.quote: The interests of users and consumer-facing businesses, particularly media businesses, are largely aligned when it comes to privacy.
The specific way in which they are enforced and implemented undermine this shared interest and only benefit adtech intermediaries, and primarily tech monopolies amongst those.
In my time leading GDPR compliance at The New York Times, if I could have had just one wish granted it would have been to reach complete single controllership.

This market structure in which the consumer-facing business doesn't retain exclusive control over its audience data is a tax on quality content, particularly premium journalism, the proceeds of which are used to subsidise disinformation and AI slop farms.
Supporting GPC is the simplest compliance work I ever did, my team implemented it across 70 products in record time.
No complex change or risky surgery is required, this change can be deployed through enforcement guidance alone.

summary: Robin Berjon, drawing on direct experience implementing GDPR at The New York Times and co-creating the Global Privacy Control standard, argues that privacy regulation should embrace automation through GPC to align user and business interests against tech monopolies. He advocates for enforcing single controllership (third parties as processors only) and recognizing GPC as a valid withdrawal of consent/objection under existing GDPR framework, requiring no legislative changes—only enforcement guidance—to deliver better privacy, reduced compliance costs, and protection of European businesses from data extraction by adtech intermediaries.
